caption:
“I endeavor to create fantastic acts, each drenched in thought-provoking whimsy,” says 25-year-old performer and National Institute of Circus Arts graduate Jesse Howard (@jessemhoward). “I love the focus and determination I can imbue into my circus training. For me, the enjoyment comes from improving while overcoming physical and mental hurdles.”⁣
⁣
And that suit? “The mirror suit was for my final act at university intended as something I could take into the industry. It took me countless hours of cutting and gluing.” #ThisWeekOnInstagram⁣
⁣
Video by @jessemhoward

Professional football freestyler Caitlyn Schrepfer (@caitfreestyle) finds inspiration from just about everything involving movement. “I like to incorporate my gymnastics and acrobatics background, along with elements from break dance and capoeira,” says the 23-year-old athlete, who tops the USA female freestyler rankings and is #2 in the world. “For me, all my tricks should flow together seamlessly one trick to the next like a well-written story.” #ThisWeekOnInstagram⁣
⁣
Photo of @caitfreestyle by @sammy.almahi
alt: A woman has one hand on the ground with her legs up in the air with a soccer ball overhead.

caption:
As a professional yo-yo performer, Shu Takada (@shu_ffle) is taking things to another level with his unique approach. “What I really want to do now is to excite people with my yo-yo performance and show how cool yo-yo can be,” says the six-time world champion, who took up the yo-yo at 6 years old.⁣
⁣
“I’ve pursued and established a new style of yo-yoing, incorporating dance and acrobatic moves,” he says. “Yo-yo may be just a toy but can also be played as a sport and be a form of artistic expression.” 🤯 #ThisWeekOnInstagram⁣
⁣
Video by @shu_ffle

#HelloFrom Scoresbysund, East Greenland, where “ice sculptures” like these can live for days, weeks or even months until they eventually crack or melt and become one with the ocean. 
Photo by @hannes_becker
alt: Image may contain: mountain, sky, outdoor, nature and water

caption:
For creator and model AJ Clementine (@ajclementine_ ), this year’s #SydneyMardiGras = a chance to celebrate her authentic self 💕. ⁣
⁣
“I’ve never experienced anything like it before,” says AJ, who participated in Sydney’s annual Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras celebration for the second year in a row. “This event provides hope, freedom and light to those who are feeling alone, invalidated or not out as themselves.” ⁣
⁣
When she’s not reveling through the streets of Sydney, the Melbourne-based 23-year-old uses her online platform to advocate for the LGBTQ community and share her life experiences about being transgender. “I grew up with little to no visibility around being trans,” says AJ. “I want to change the narrative and show a different story.”

On today’s #WeeklyFluff we are seeing double with sister act Paris and Luna (@paristheminipig), two mini potbellied pigs with maxi style. 🐷 ⁣
⁣
Video by @paristheminipig

When photographer Caroline Heggdal (@iseecaroline) turned to makeup art as a creative outlet a couple of years ago, she found a floral focus through her avant-garde eye art. “I quickly discovered that your face (or eye) could have so many possibilities for creative art that wasn’t the typical pen on paper,” she says. “The eye for me shows true emotion, soul and it never really lies.” 🌸👁🌸#ThisWeekOnInstagram⁣
⁣
Photo by @iseecaroline
alt: Close-up of an eye, with blue eye shadow, and tiny white flowers on the eyelid.

caption:
Meet creator and entrepreneur Jackie Aina (@jackieaina), an advocate for inclusivity and diversity. Jackie’s success in demanding more representation within the beauty industry has inspired millions of people around the world, but most don’t know the struggle it took Jackie to get to this point. 💞 ⁣
✨ ⁣
Growing up in Los Angeles, sometimes living in shelters, Jackie didn’t have a lot of positive role models to teach her about success. “I wish I had people around showing me what it looks like to live out your passion,” says Jackie. “When you see someone who is young and is Black and is killing it and is not allowing their upbringing to affect their adulthood, I want people to be inspired by that. If I could be that to somebody else, then I really, really hope I can be.” ⁣
✨ ⁣
While Jackie is busy building her own empire, she’s also mentoring other creators and making sure they have opportunities to use their platforms in a positive way. “For me, #ShareBlackStories is another way of saying share Black experiences. We can all relate to and learn from each other in one way or another.” ⁣
✨ ⁣
This Black History Month, we’ve partnered with @bet to #ShareBlackStories and support #Advocates doing amazing work on Instagram and beyond. Check out our final episode, on IGTV now.
alt: A woman wears a blue headpiece and blue dress.

caption:
“I want to see all versions of the Black woman flourish. I want to see the bougie Black girl. I want to see the geeky Black girl. I want to see the Black girl who does cosplay. I feel like there’s room for all of us. But there shouldn’t be this hierarchy of one being better than the other. I’m just here for every version of Blackness,” says Jackie, a creator and entrepreneur from Los Angeles. ❤️️🖤 ⁣
“I’m a voice for inclusivity because I refuse to let Black women go unnoticed. I will always do what I can to make sure that it just doesn’t happen.”⁣
⁣
For Black History Month, we’ve partnered with @bet to #ShareBlackStories and support #Advocates who are inspiring those in the black community and beyond. Watch our final episode on IGTV. 🖤❤️️

Editorial fashion and beauty MUA Martha Butterworth (@marthamakeupartist) doesn’t like to be pigeonholed. “I prefer to try out as many ideas and techniques as possible,” says Martha, who often uses 3D elements in her work, “purely because it opens up a whole new dimension to what I can create.”⁣
⁣
“A lot of my work is colorful and has a light-hearted fun element to it,” she says. “I think I get bored quite quickly and feel the need to break the mold.” 🌞⁣
⁣
Photo by @marthamakeupartist
alt: A woman with green eyebrows wearing glasses that are covered in fake lawn and plastic figurines.
